												A creative, inventive, and intelligent experiment ... that ultimately fails.First off, the price tag is cheeky. I'm sure a lot of effort went into making this game, but the same is true for many independent games that are cheap or free. Some humility is in order here.The mix of photography and film is gorgeous and very evocative, though calling it "real-time 3D technology" is plain deceptive, because the scenes are all in 2D. The voice acting is good enough, the music forgettable but fitting.Make no mistake, despite the artistic pretense this is intended to be a playable game. As such, it's a bad one: a very hard hidden-object game with "secrets" instead of puzzles. The game might take a few hours to complete if you play it without a walkthrough, but those would be frustrating hours for most of us.(Note that I am talking about completing the whole game. You can also breeze through it in 45 minutes without seeing much of the secret content and alternate endings of chapters. When reviews say this game is "short and easy," that's what they mean. The whole game is very hard.)The problem is that the difficulty of finding the collectible objects (photographs) is due entirely to the incredibly obtuse navigation controls: the player is not otherwise presented with challenges requiring creative thought. The perspective is first person, but your normal sense of direction will confuse rather than guide you, because the photographic angles tell you almost nothing about which direction you will be heading or what exits are available. The map you should be building in your head would be a tree-like structure of locations that has almost nothing to do with the physical layout. You'll miss objects not because you are a bad detective, but because you have no idea how to get to where you want to go.Even with a walkthrough I cannot recommend this game. The revealed secrets do not cohere into a meaningful narrative or image: it's just a few fragments from the life, memories, and observations of a young, middle-class, female European university student. Despite the poetic pomp, there's nothing deep about her mutterings. There is potential for a deeper meaning, but it is left undeveloped.I'm happy that developers experiment with video games and try to move beyond our expectations of how they should look and feel. In this case, it didn't work out, and it would be nice if the developers acknowledge this and set a more appropriate price tag.

												TRAUMA is very much an arthouse game, and as vague as that is it should tell you right away if you'll have the patience for it. There's no deep gameplay or clear story to be found here, just a lot of clicking and speculation. This is by no means a bad thing, as I will expand upon, but its not going to be for everyone.The title refers to the car accident and subsequent hospitalization of the main character, a terribly disaffected European woman. You'll be playing through her dreams as she lies in her hospital bed, mulling over the choices she's made in life. The game is divided into four dreams, each presented as a series of still photographs. Clicking on hotspots or gesturing with the mouse moves you from one photograph to the next, simulating movement through the celluloid environment. You've probably played something like it on a Flash site, where someone took a bunch of pictures of the alley next to their house and cobbled them into a 10-minute adventure game.TRAUMA is a little more involved than that, thankfully. Each dream has a goal that must be accomplished using a special gesture learned in that dream. These gestures can also be used in other dreams to unlock alternate endings and paths. In addition to the goal and three alternate endings, each dream also contains nine photographs to find within the photographed world. Some of these give additional background on your character's life, some teach new gestures for moving around, and some give clues to the alternate endings. They can be tricky to find due to the wonky angles of some scenes, but getting all the endings for a dream unlocks a "photo sense" that gives you vague but useful feedback on how far away a photo is.During your explorations, your character will narrate what you see in her best deadpan Bjork voice. A lot of this is philosophical meandering like wondering if she's every really connected with anyone, but it makes a good backdrop for your actual meandering. The environments are also more than just photo club art projects, with some limited CG added for dreamlike features. Overall it's the atmosphere of TRAUMA that most appeals to me, the combination of quiet, unaffected musing with a journey through familiar scenes made alien by the way they are chopped into stills. The audio does a lot to prop up this feeling, with understated sound effects and a low minimalist soundtrack that's just the right amount of menacing.Despite the appeal, I still have some bones to pick with the design. Like with any photographic adventure game, some of the connections between scenes don't make a whole lot of sense. Some clicks will tilt your head a little, others will send you into the next zip code. The fourth dream in particular has a layout that is sure to aggravate, with multiple transitions that could only be accomplished with teleportation. And don't expect any sort of explicit resolution or pathos to the story, because you're either going to get a total non-ending or a slightly cryptic non-ending, depending on if you find all the photographs.If you've read this far and are still with me, TRAUMA is probably a game that will hold your interest. There's only an hour or so of exploration total, but it nails that dreamworld feel that so many games shoot for and miss. And if you do dive into it, maybe you can extract more from the story than I could. I appreciate unique experiences in games, and while TRAUMA might not be groundbreaking or even deep in its gameplay, there's enough to see and feel to make it a worthwhile experience.

												Trauma is a casual Point-&-Click adventure game but with a slight twist. In the game, you play a young woman exploring her dreams shortly after a car accident that kills her parents and hospitalizes her. The dreams serves as metaphors for her life, exploring her childhood, her time in college, her relationship with her parents, and her feelings on her life. The dreams sequences are made up of real life photographs, which are nothing short of breath taking, arranged in a way to create a sort of segemented 3D environment. While this seems like it would lend itself to some interesting puzzles, it does not. In fact, Trauma lacks puzzles, however, instead favoring a drawing mechanic.There are four drawings in the game (Lift, Catch, Drain, Cut) and each one allows you to interact with cetain objects in each dream to unlocks different endings. The drawing mechanic, however, is not deep, at least not mechanically, and serves more as a tool for exploring the metaphor of a dream.  For instance, there is a dream where you are running along a road and come to a wall. You obviously can't Lift, Catch, or Cut the wall but the wall does have a drain on it, thus allowing you to Drain the wall. However, when you drain the wall and move past it, you find yourself right back where you started with the game zooming out to show the world is a small sphere. Overall, the game is intesting. It's beautiful, does some unusual things and ends up touching upon certain things that most games fail to.

The main protagonist--lets be honest, she is basically the only real character in this story--has just survived a traumatic accident. Now bedridden for an unknown period of time, she finds herself dreaming the same dreams over and over. It took me about an hour to beat the game, with only a few alternate endings not found. And yet this doesn't detract my overall opinion of the game. Something about the German narrator (voiced beautifully by Anja Jazeschann) really struck me as detached, hopeless, confused--it really gave me a sense of urgency as I tried to piece together the photographs and search for clues on how to end this infinite loop of depression. If you are curious as to the insight dreams give to outsiders, especially those of a trauma victim, I do not think you will be disappointed with this inexpensive indie gem.

												TL;DR: Interesting concept, but incredibly pretentious and barely a game.TRAUMA's concept is interesting: Exploring surreal dreamscapes, and gradually learning ways to interact with them, allowing you to later go back and experience previous worlds in a different way. Each dream can be "solved" in several different ways.Unfortunately, the execution falls well short. The dreams are tiny, static environments, and confusing to navigate. In fact, you can't "walk" at all; you have a series of pictures, and you draw glyphs on the screen to move around. This may have been forgivable in the mid-90s, but this game was made in 2011! Every screen can have a half-dozen different exits, depending on how the writer was feeling that day.There are no puzzles to speak of. Each dream is "won" by drawing the right glyph in the right spot. You're treated to a small animation, a line or two of voiceover narration, and the next dream is unlocked. If you solve a dream "incorrectly" (i. e. by using the right glyph in the right spot, but a different glyph than the one you "learn" in the dream)... you're treated to a small animation, a line or two of voiceover narration, and then told to go back and do it correctly. Whee.There's a collection sidequest - pictures hidden in each dream - which is nice if you enjoy pixel hunts. It takes about twice as long as the game itself and adds 5 seconds to the ending cutscene. These 5 seconds tell you exactly nothing new about the protagonist (her every other line is "everything is still terrible") and only serve to make the ending slightly more depressing. It took me less than two hours to finish the game, about half of which was pixel hunting.In short: TRAUMA has paper-thin gameplay, the writing is cryptic-for-the-sake-of-being-cryptic and highly pretentious. The dream concept is interesting, and the game has a memorable moment or two, but in the end, it is overwhelmingly flawed. Unless you're extremely desparate for any sort of adventure game at all, no recommendation.

It’s a kind of point and click game, a woman who is in the hospital narrates her thoughts and you search and explore her dreams looking for answers and picking up little collectables along the way that give you extra little pieces of information about her life.I really like the style of this game, the scenes are made up of photographs that you flick between and it uses a few photography methods which I thought was quite clever. For example it uses low shutter speed methods to show movement in the photos and ghostly figures. (Low shutter speed being where you take the photo but it carries on taking in light through the lens, so if someone were to jump into the photo while it was still taking in light, it would pick up the light reflected off of the person. Hence pictures of “ghosts”) It’s a pretty short game, but I guess it’s only a small indie game so that is to be expected. It’s fun and interesting and really does have a surreal “dream” like feel to it, which I can imagine could be quite hard to portray. The cut scenes also add greatly to that, them being inventive and surreal reflects the mind of the dreamer pretty well. It’s put together well and is worth a try by anyone interested in unique little point and clicks or maybe even just photography.

												It's an interesting idea, at least.The game looks interesting and the gimic of moving around from photo to photo while using magic symbols to interact with the game's world has some potential. The art and photography is appealing, especially when it suddenly does something weird, like suddenly sucking up a random billboard or shattering a ghost. It's imagery is a strong aspect.It's just that it has no overal point. At best, the game is cryptic. At worst, the game has nothing to say. As a jaunt into someone's dreams and psyche, you'd think you'd come away learning a great deal about that person, right? I couldn't find any value to that assumption. Most of the details given about this woman's identity as a character don't ever appear to connect. She went to Uni, she went to a coffee shop once, she had a teddy bear. Why should I care?It doesn't necessarily connect or amount to any revelation about the character. There's no real coherrence about this towards any real goal. It's just weirdness from beginning to end. I'm sure it's the point; to allow for your own interpretation of what to make of all this but I struggle to find that satisfying. It doesn't seem to justify it's own existance by offering any conclusion to take from the journey made. Perhaps this is meant to be from the point of view of the Doctor tending to this woman? It would explain the tiny amount of information we gleam from her dreams and bits of information from them, only to have the game end abruptly. What drags this still lower in my opinion is how boring the gameplay is.One of the larger flaws is how entertaining the game is. The 'puzzles' are no more advanced than find a thing and perform a special symbol on it to get something to happen. Nothing amounts to anything more than just an alternative ending. That also seems to be weirdness for weirdness' sake. If you learn what does what and what will only work with what, your only challenge is to spot what looks interactive and what isn't. This is not all that hard either. If you can be bothered, you'll breeze through this within an hour and a half. If you like weird things, you won't feel too bad if you get it during a sale. Otherwise, it's not that remarkable. For a flash game this bland, it feels overpriced. Go play one of the weirder looking things on Armour Games. It's free and likely more entertaining than this.

												With titles like these I'm reminded of the so-called golden age of FMV gaming, brought on by CD-ROM drives. Horribly clunky, dysfunctional pieces of puppetry and grainy video. Okay, I'm making this all sound awful, aren't I? Well, what I meant to say is that perhaps personal computers are fast enough these days to make those approaches plausible. Maybe we didn't hate those experimental games, but the fact that the technology to run them properly didn't exist? No more macroblocky and grainy 64-colour video and sluggish screen transitions. Trauma is short but lovably dreamlike -- and not at all hindered by the technology onto which it is born, unlike most of its 1990s relatives. Trauma is also bleak.

												Not enough...Trauma is point and click puzzle game developed by Krystian Majewski.Story isn't great. You basically play as a girl who has been in a car accident. She is now in hospital recovering, and has a variety of dreams which hide her past memories. Ending wasn't that great either.Gameplay is weakest element in the box. Basically there are four levels. In order to solve puzzles, you need to draw specific symbols on certain items (which will be shown to you early on). There are also hidden photographs which show a bit about the girl's past or other symbols you can draw. You can play each of those levels again to try to find the alternative endings if you want, but after completing the game, I really wasn't compelled enough to go back and replay levels. I completed the game (unlocking one ending each puzzle) within 25 minutes, which I personally felt was quite short. Audio is quite haunting. Not sure if this is a good thing for a puzzle game, but the music sound spooky and gives a somewhat uneasy fealing when solving puzzles. The voice acting doesn't sound that great, but at least the girl's voice further adds to the spooky atmosphere.Graphics is the main highlight here. The images used for puzzle solving are real life photographs. These are show alot of detail and is somewhat attarctive to look at. Unless you really want to look at some pretty pictures and do minimal puzzle solving, I can't recommend this game (especially at full price).

Posted: April 27, 2016
												There is an easy way you can play this game without paying for it; on a windy day at night time take 10 photos from your family's photo album and throw them out the window. While you search for them in the empty streets think about your childhood, your parents, your dreams, the choices you made that led you to where you are now, and ask where is it all going. If you are a young adult still searching for your place in this world, then you probably already had these thoughts and questions, so you already "played the game". Don't expect to find any answers to those questions here.STORYTELLING, DESIGN AND GAMEPLAYEven though the idea of exploring these girl's troubling thoughts via her dreams is rather interesting the execution fails in many ways. The story and the girl have no depth. There are no long monologues that would lead you a bit deeper into her past or her mind, all you get is obvious symbolism, and one or two sentences describing the location or the photos she found. You wont get to know this girl, her family or friends, and she seems to be the most average person you can imagine with the most common problems we all have.The maps are made using an old technique where the environment is a slideshow of static photos, and you click on the part of photo to move to that area. There are also some 3D animations at the end of the dreams. The game is released in 2011 and the resolution of the photos is 640x480. There is simply no excuse for such low quality images in 2011. Other than that the locations of the dreams are visually not very interesting, plus they are very small. In the first dream/location you can only look around, you don't even move, and other dreams are just a 50 meter long walk in one direction. You can click through the whole game in 10 minutes.You have 4 dreams/locations and each one has 1 main and 3 alternative endings. You can also collect 9 photos in each dream. The various endings are just some random symbolic 3D animations followed by the girl's short comment. Then you are sent to the main menu, and you need to restart the dream to see what the other endings/animations are about. Constant switching from game to menu just breaks the immersion.You trigger the ending by drawing a certain shape on a certain location... and that is it. It is all made so easy that in the first dream the solution is drawn on your first screen 6 times !!! Solutions for other endings can be found either in the photos or glowing somewhere in the environment, you can't miss it. Other photos either explain the controls to move around or they are some random photo from the girls past. There are only around 10 personal photos in the whole game, but each dream contains the same photos explaining the same controls. That is simply ridiculous, instead of using the photos to tell me more about the girl, they repeat the same control instructions 4 times. It's such a waste.CONCLUSIONThe photos can be tricky to find, and after I finished the game for the first time, I was expecting that finding all the photos and getting all the various endings for each dream will give me a new "good" final ending that will give some closure to all this, but it didn't. The new ending video had few different shots, but there was no change overall. The whole game feels like a blend of various missed opportunities that could have led to a very interesting experience.

Short:+ A coherent, to some people probably interesting design (I'm somewhat undecided)+ Interesting topic- Very simple - too simple - gameplay (clicking/drawing through warped photos)- Not much to do generally- Topic stays rather superficial, perhaps pretentious- Irritating voice actressLong:I am planning to play it again sometime. My impressions so far aren't the best. It has been a long time since I played it, but I still wish to give my opinion on it.I've tried feeling into it, but it didn't work too well. This game tries to deliver some emotional narration and story, but it didn't strike me. It rather felt pretentious and weakly executed. You are moving through some dreams or memorized pictures of a woman after some car accident while restoring at a hospital. It could have been a dreamy, surreal game but felt too simple: You move through photos of real-life places by clicking around them or (as seen in games like "Arx Fatalis", "The Void" or "Black & White") by drawing symbols on the screen which you first discover in somewhat hidden areas of these photos. The photos were distorted with warped lightnings and all to give them some surreal feeling. However even I as a layman can tell that this is something you can probably easily do with Photoshop, or by making mistakes when taking these photos you would otherwise want to avoid. Then there are a few rather simple CG animations put in these photos. And cutscenes which didn't feel >that< bad but which are real-life footages, more often than not close-ups of a female actor pretending to be unconscious for most of it giving some hints towards the meanings of her dreams as well as her restoration from the accident. I didn't like her voice actress too much. I had some feeling of boredom and apathy listening to her. Perhaps this is how someone in such a situation would sound like, to give some feeling of emptiness and aimlessness, but this is naturally nothing one feels drawn to, and in combination with the rather simple gameplay and general "sterile" feeling of this game it somehow added to me feeling the whole of it to be lacking.So, I don't know, the concept sounded interesting, but there really isn't too much to do in this game. Navigating through warped photos isn't exactly something that takes a massive effort game design-wise I guess, and as simple as it sounds so it did feel when I played it. Not exactly bad, but far from being impressive either. I think there could have been a lot more to do with this topic, seeing some woman questioning aspects of her life and identity could carry power and meaning, but it felt rather superficial as this woman was partly dealing with things someone probably could get over very early in one's life like chasing fake dreams of stars or those dictated by leading figures in one's life. This is something I can't sympathize with, as it has some touch of immaturity I cannot really relate to anymore.

												I don't know how this "game" has a "mixed" reception. It's more of a collection of images than a point-and-click or hidden object game, really. The entire game is presented as a 360 degree panoramic picture and the main objective is discovering all the angles. Think google map's street view. It feels more like someone's phototophy portfolio or a proof of concept, not a finished product. Discovering the angles isn't much about puzzle solving or wits, moreso just finding the right approach to access the area you want. If you appreciate urban photography with an amateur attempt to photoshop a surreal environment, you might find it interesting. But really, even from that approach it's hard to like. I've seen a few comparisons to Dear Esther, a walking simulator that I found to be quite enjoyable. It's nothing like Dear Esther. Dear Esther relied on an attention to detail in a beautifully designed 3D world that you could explore. There is no world to explore in Trauma - just essentially a folder of images from a day's photography of a city. This game cuts corners to deliver plot with stale 2D images as plot device "collectibles" in the form of Polaroids. There is nothing to actually interact with or trigger except alternate endings and main endings that abruptly end the level. This is the slideshow version of Dear Esther - something that DOESN'T work. The most redeeming thing about it are the cutscenes which are actually fairly well-done snippets of filmography. For one, it's incredibly short and can be completed in less than an hour. With some games, this is forgivable. But, with "TRAUMA" it is not. If a game is short, I expect the experience to be top notch. If a game is bad, I at least expect it to be longer to win me over. The story reads like a psychological thriller. But, it's done in too little time to make it interesting or captivating. The objective is completely pointless, too. Yes, it's a dream so nothing should make sense, but the first chapter's primary objective is to get a rock off of a teddy bear. I was expecting that to trigger some other objective. Nope. Film scene, then end. The controls remind me of a DS game where you draw command with a the stylus (in this case a mouse). For instance, a horseshoe makes you view what's behind you. But most of the time, it's just a quicker way to "turn around." It also allows you to interact with the environment to trigger alternate endings - alternate endings that come down to "I like coffee, but I usually have it during the day. This time, it's at night." Whoopty do. Half of the time, the recognition is bad and leads to you inputting a completely different command which accidentally triggers a plot ending, the FMV associated with it, and brings you to the main menu. If you want surreal, hop on an art site and save your $7. It's much higher quality and much more interesting. This isn't really a game and is moreso an artsy display of someones photography/graphic design mixed with a short-film that is laid out badly.

												Trauma may seem deceptively simple at first: it's a flash game about exploring the dreams of a girl who's been through an accident. It will probably take 30 min to an hour to finish the main path, yet there are hidden secrets and alternate ways to end a dream.Trauma is all about exploration and is very light on the challenge. It plays like an out of body experience. The main puzzle is navigation through a set of mouse gestures. The girl will narrate the dream logic as she recognizes signs from her real past. Each dream has a core dilemma that needs to be solved. The light gameplay is more than compensated by the depth of story ideas. Through each dream, you start knowing more about the protagonist and by the end, symbols start falling into place. The dreams are interconnected; you will find recurring ideas, and some solutions are applicable in more than one situation.Trauma is best played right before bed. It will make you think about the stuff that goes through your head at night.

												When I bought this game I was on an adventure game kick and an indie game kick and steam was scrathing that particular itch at the time. The game appeared to be an interesting little indie adventiure game based on running through mazes, collecting clues, solving puzzles, etc. all while telling a rich story, through gameplay and abstract symbolism. It was supposed to ba a tale of a woman who, while in a quasi-concious state, unravels the story of her demise and/or recounts the regrets in her life, ultimately finding a way to acheive some sense of inner peace or resolve some internal conflict; perhaps while having an out of body experience as she dies or edges closer to death. All this seemed interesting to me as an adeventure game player and I was excited to unravel the mysteries of this womans life and what exactly had happened to her. WHAT I GOT, was what appeared to be a slideshow of random industrial and urban set pieces that resembled something you might be shown by a friend who just went on a walk with thier first DSLR camera. The story was so abstracted and boring, and there were no puzzle elements or really any clues to find at all. You can beat the game or more accurately "complete the interactive experience" in about 20-45 min by simply moving from frame to frame and clicking on everything. The word game doesnt really apply as there is no challenge or any sense of completeing anything at the end, its more of an activity center for manic depressives. Threre seems to be no resolution of conflict (nor any conflict in general) in the story, and even if there were its conveyed so poorly and in such a boring manner that I couldn't have cared less anyways.   Moreover I feel especially cheated for buying this for about 6-7 $ US expecting to be puzzled and challenged for at least the better part of 7-8 hours, only to then "finish the experience" in under 30 min, with no recourse for return or exchange. Do yourself a favor and do not waste any money on this "interactive experience", which was clearly designed by people who thought it was so edgy, unique, indie and deep (when it is none of these things) that it could rest on those laurels without anything resembling what would be objectively considered a game. Some might say that Dear Esther could be given the same criticism, however DE is a much richer experience, immerseive in its beautifully exectued graphics and sound desgin which (with a little help from headphones and a dark room) can transport the player into the setting giving them a large sense of immersion. DE is also short hoever, I feel I could explore the island of DE for hours (and have) and there is more value in it to me based on the immersive experience it creates. While DE is not technically a game it IS a well crafted "interactive experience" the mystery surrounding the letters and clues you find on the island are abstract and cryptic enough not to spell everything out for you, but are engaging and keep you wanting to search the island in an effort to discover what happend and why its important. Trauma on the other hand fails as an "interactive experience" as much as it does as a game. The choice to move from boring still to still and mediocre sound design make the experience wholly non-imersive. The story is also so abstracted, disjointed and boring that by the end you dont care what is going on or why, thus you have no insentive to continue "coimpleting the experience". Trauma fails miserably as a game and even more so as an "interactive experience", if you are intrigued by Trauma, dont bother and buy Dear Esther instead becuase clearly more love and care went into making it and it is a much richer experience on the whole.

Posted: April 5, 2016
												A woman is in a car accident.  Join her as she dreams while in the hospital, and search for clues about her past in her subconscious.  This is TRAUMA, a Flash-based game by Krystian Majewski.The woman has four recurring dreams, and you must help her complete each one.  Each dream sequence is depicted as a series of connected photographs that you click through Myst-style.  Manipulate objects and move in the world by drawing symbols, and collect photographs of the woman’s memories.The puzzles are simple, but sometimes finding them is not.  Some of the photographs are hints about how to complete the alternate dream endings in other levels, which is a nice way to encourage you to go back and poke around all of them.  Once you complete every ending in a level, you are given the ability to sense when uncollected photos are close to you, giving you an easier time finding that last hidden nugget of information about this girl.TRAUMA is an interesting game visually, as the photos used feel like a real place, though the lens flares and ‘ghosts’ that inhabit the frames are unsettling.  Just like in a dream, you never really meet anyone else, and you often know what you’re “supposed” to do, though you can end the dream in many ways.There is a camera shutter *click* every time you move throughout the world, which can be a tiny bit irritating as you go about exploring.  The music, though, is quiet and thoughtful, almost more background noise than soundtrack.  It adds a nice layer of sonic calmness to the game.This game took me 90 minutes to complete.  That might be because it isn’t really a game in the traditional sense.  It’s better described as a piece of art.  The woman’s dreams are reflections of her conversations with the doctor.  You’ll understand this woman’s personality and motivations, but the car accident doesn’t define her.  It isn’t even really mentioned after the first cutscene.  No, TRAUMA is all about understanding this girl’s psyche.imageAnd it does a great job of that.  I feel like I know her, even though I only spent an hour and a half with her.  She has hopes and dreams, both old and new, both possible and crushed.  Her mind has regret and stress, but it is also full of wonder, passion, and curiosity.  This is a mature game, not because it has violence or sex.  Instead, the way it deals with emotional themes that are difficult to grasp.  TRAUMA isn’t defined by the tightness of its gameplay, but by the greatness of its content.  If you have a couple hours to spare, poking around this girl’s dreams is a great way to spend it.I just realized I don’t even know her name.
